value.value: An artifact resulting from scatter of the beam by a dense object.
A CT number underestimation artifact resulting from the presence of a dense object off center in a scan field.
An artifact resulting from absorpsion of lower energy photons as the beam penetrates through a tissue.
An artifact that is due to a group of channels or views that deviate gradually from the true measurement.
An artifact that is due to errors in an individual detector calibration.
An artifact resulting from an inconsistency in a single measurement.
The reemergence of non-Hodgkin lymphoma transformed after a period of remission.
An artifact resulting from data processing steps after capture of an image.
An artifact resulting from the leakage of an imaging agent from its location of administration.
An artifact that results when an imaging agent is not absorbed or metabolized at the expected rate.
An artifact resulting from excess signal at the injection site.
An artifact resulting from the contamination of the imaging field with an extraneous body substance.
Artifacts that result when the grid frequency is too low or when the grid orientation is parallel to the scan direction.
An artifact resulting from factors within the object being imaged.
An artifact resulting from the presence of a foreign body between the target and the receiver.
An artifact resulting from a problem with the patient.
An artifact resulting from the specific anatomy of the patient.
A malignant mesothelioma extensively involving the pericardium.
Artifacts related to the physique or body build of the patient.
An artifact resulting from a patient with a large body size or body mass.
An artifact resulting from the presence of another body structure between the target and the receiver.
An artifact resulting from the incorrect positioning of the patient.
An image artifact that results in unexpected signals due to patient physiology or problem metabolizing an imaging agent.
An imaging artifact resulting from a patient arrhythmia.
An imaging artifact resulting from a patient left bundle branch block.
An imaging artifact resulting from hyperglycemia of the patient.
An artifact resulting from movement of the patient during image capture.

label.value: Faulty Instrument or Use of Instrument Artifact

value.value: An artifact resulting from the use of defective equipment or from improper use of equipment.
A malignant mesothelioma that arises from the peritoneum and has spread in the abdominal cavity.  It may result in bowel obstruction.
Artifacts resulting from the electronics of the plate reader or from issues associated with the image plate.
An image of reduced quality resulting from the application of the wrong mask.
An image of reduced quality resulting from the application of a mask in the wrong way.
An image of reduced quality resulting from the application of too many masks.
An image of reduced quality resulting from the application of too few masks.
An image of reduced quality resulting from the use of incorrect or incomplete instructions.
An image of reduced quality resulting from the use of instructions with missing steps.
An image of reduced quality resulting from the use of the wrong instructions.
An image of reduced quality due to the collection or rejection of the wrong signal frequencies.
An image containing random signal.
The reemergence of malignant peritoneal mesothelioma after a period of remission.
Putting an end to doubt or question; leading to final results or an outcome.
An immunohistochemical diagnostic test utilizing an antibody to detect p16 in tissues.

label.value: In Situ Hybridization Analysis of HPV 16 DNA Sequences

value.value: An in situ hybridization diagnostic test utilizing fluorescent probes to detect HPV 16 DNA sequences in tissues.
Any agent that binds to and activates any of the adrenergic receptors.

A standard measure of visceral obesity, or abdominal fat, which is measured from the patient's back to upper abdomen between the bottom of the rib cage and the top of the pelvic area. This measurement may be taken with the patient standing or in the supine position.

label.value: Oropharyngeal Human Papillomavirus-Related Squamous Cell Carcinoma

value.value: A squamous cell carcinoma that arises from the oropharynx and is associated with human papillomavirus type 16 infection.

A combination preparation containing the belladonna alkaloids atropine sulfate, hyoscyamine sulfate, and scopolamine hydrobromide, and the barbiturate phenobarbital with antispasmodic, anxiolytic and sedative activities. The belladonna alkaloids bind to and block muscarinic receptors in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. This leads to a decrease in stomach secretions, GI motility and GI spasms. Phenobarbital binds to a distinct site on the gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA)-A subtype receptor in the central nervous system (CNS), thereby increasing the influx of chloride ions into the neuron and potentiating GABA-induced increases in chloride conductance. This enhances postsynaptic responses to the inhibitory actions of GABA and causes CNS depression.

A triazolo-benzodiazepine derivative with sedative, hypnotic, anxiolytic and anticonvulsant activities. Brotizolam binds to the benzodiazepine binding site on the gamma aminobutyric acid (GABA)-A receptor in the central nervous system (CNS). This leads to an increase in the opening of chloride channels, membrane hyperpolarization and increases the inhibitory effect of GABA on the CNS.

A combination preparation containing the polypeptide antibiotic polymyxin b, the aminoglycoside antibiotic neomycin, the glucocorticoid hydrocortisone and, in some formulations, the antibiotic bacitracin zinc with antibacterial and anti-inflammatory activities.  Polymyxin B, neomycin and bacitracin zinc exert antibacterial effects through a cationic detergent-like action on cell membranes, inhibition of protein synthesis, and inhibition of peptidoglycan synthesis, respectively. Hydrocortisone initially binds to the cytoplasmic glucocorticoid receptor; then the receptor-ligand complex is translocated to the nucleus where it initiates the transcription of genes encoding for anti-inflammatory mediators, such as cytokines and lipocortins.

A group of compounds similar to prostaglandins with immunomodulating activity. Isoprostanes are formed through free radical catalyzing non-enzymatic reactions involving peroxidation of essential fatty acids, mainly arachidonic acid or any other fatty acid with 3 or more double bonds. Isoprostanes are abundant in tissues and fluids and their concentration is dependent on the amount of oxidative stress and may be upregulated in certain diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular and neurological disorders.
